717625f-a.text:
Broadway (then known as Boulevard), west side, from 72nd to 74th Streets, showing the Hotel St. Andrew in the foreground, and the Rutgers Memorial Church. The Hotel St. Andrew will stand in 1936, but the church will give way between 1920 and 1925 to a
five-story building.
About 1895.
Brown Brothers.
According to the New York Times of October 3, 1937, the Hotel built in 1893, will be replaced by a 4 or 5-story business structure. This site was the result (to himself and at a total cost of only ~6,500) of a shrewd land speculation deal, by Robert Robertson in January 1886. It became the property of Morris Schinasi, the cigarette manufacturer at a later date si whose heirs are involved in the present transfer.
Nleg 4t2Al

717623f-a.text:
(1)
Eroadway at the S.E. corner of 72nd Street. Ih the background
is the Dorilton, and behind it, the Hotel Alamac.
April 3, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
This 5-story corner structure that is partially obscured by signs will be demolished and replaced by a modern 2-story structure according
to the New York Times of November 28, 1937.
(2)
Broadway,Fest Side,looking North between West 7Ist and Test 72nd Streets. The elaborate facade of building on the right is
the Eastern exposure of the Dorilton Apartments.
October 9th,I240
